This executive summary provides a brief overview of the Risk Management Program (RMP) and the associated policies at the Tupelo Wastewater Treatment Plant, owned by the City of Tupelo and operated by ESG Operations, Inc.

1.0	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

ESG Operations, Inc. believes it is important to provide a safe workplace to its employees and minimize the impact of its operations on the surrounding community and the environment.  Accordingly, ESG has developed a proactive safety and environmental programs, which rely upon active employee participation and management leadership and support.  This same proactive philosophy was employed in the development and implementation of the Tupelo Wastewater Treatment Plant RMP for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems.  ESG Operations, Inc. has determined that the OSHA Process Safety Management standard also applies to the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage and chlorination/dechlorination processes and therefore has prepared this RMP to comply with the RMP Program 3 requirements.  By doing so, ESG affirms its proactive safety and environmental philosophy and acknowledges the inherent value of full RMP compliance.

The RMP prevention program is arguably the most important element of the rule.  Its program elements require the active participation of facility employees and management in conducting activities aimed at preventing accidental releases of chlorine and sulfur dioxide, regulated chemicals under the RMP regulation.  If prevention activities could be completely successful, there would be no need for emergency response activities, since no releases would occur.  Accordingly, a well-developed and properly implemented prevention program will lower the possibility of an accidental release and minimize the consequences of a release should one occur.

ESG Operations, Inc. takes an active role in preventing accidental releases by ensuring that its employees are well-informed rega

rding the hazards associated with chlorine and sulfur dioxide at the Tupelo Wastewater Treatment Plant and actively participate in process hazard analysis.  The chlorine/sulfur dioxide storage and chlorination/dechlorination processes have not changed since the time of the first RMP submission in June 1999.  The employees that work on the systems are properly trained in the safe operation and handling of these systems.  Refresher training is provided to the employees regularly.  They are aided in this work by standard operating procedures.

ESG Operations, Inc. management understands its duty to provide a safe working environment and to take measures to prevent accidents which may have an effect on the surrounding community.  Additionally, ESG Operations, Inc. has established procedures for emergency notification and response. 

2.0 Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Tupelo Wastewater Treatment Plant owned by the City of Tupelo is located at 2062 International Drive in Tupelo, Lee County, Mississippi.  The Tupelo WWTP treats wastewater through a series of physical and chemical treatment operations.  ESG operates the City of Tupelo's activated sludge wastewater treatment plant consisting of fine screening and grit removal, orbals (oxidation ditch), circular clarifiers and chlorine contact chambers followed by cascade aeration.  The project also operates and maintains in excess of 100 lift stations and various lagoons throughout the city and county.  The plant is designed to treat an average daily flow of 8.0 MGD and a peak average daily flow of 12 MGD.

The Tupelo WWTP utilizes chlorine as a biocide in the treatment of wastewater and sulfur dioxide as a dechlorinating agent prior to discharge.  The  City of Tupelo is regulated under the RMP rule because of the quantities of both chlorine and sulfur dioxide stored and used at the facility.  As required by the RMP Regulation, ESG Operations, Inc. has updated the Offsite Consequence Analysis.

maintains an Emergency Response Program that is coordinated with local response agencies, including the Tupelo Fire Department.  The program is described in detail in the manual and meets the requirements of 40 CFR 68.95, which includes facility notification to emergency responders and evacuation procedures.  The goals of the program are to protect onsite employees from the hazardous effects of chlorine or sulfur dioxide release and to minimize the effects of such releases on the general public.  This program is routinely reviewed and updated to reflect personnel and regulatory changes.

6.0	Planned changes for Improved Safety

Ideas for changes to improve safety are actively sought from employees.  Employee participation meetings which focus on safety issues are held regularly at the Tupelo WPCP.  Employees are encouraged and trained to recognize hazards and to present ideas to eliminate them or to minimize the potential consequences of such hazards.

As part of the development of the Tupelo WPCP program, the PHA was revalidated with key employees to meet the prevention program requirements.  The first PHA was performed in 1999, the PHA review/revalidation in 1999, 2004, 2007 and 2008, 2010, 2013, 2015, 2017 and 2020  The findings of subsequent compliance audits were reviewed for completion and are included in the plan.

4.0	Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention 
Steps

Prevention Steps for Chlorine

The prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps are described in detail in the Tupelo WPCP RMP manual.  The prevention program includes the following elements:

3.1	Process safety information, which includes information pertaining to the hazards of chlorine in the process, process technology and process equipment
3.2	Process hazard analysis (PHA), which includes a systematic evaluation of the hazards of the chlorine process, identification of previous process incidents, engineering and administrative controls, consequences of failure of the engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors, and possible safety and health effects of failure of controls.
3.3	Operating procedures, which include steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations and safety systems and their functions.
3.4	Training for each Tupelo WPCP employee involved in operating the chlorine system.
3.5	Mechanical integrity procedures to maintain the on-going integrity of the chlorine process equipment.
3.6	Management of change procedure to manage changes (other than replacements in kind) to the chlorine system.  The management of change procedures were reviewed in May 2008, August 2010, June 2012, March 2013, March 2015, June 2017, March 2018 and June 2020
3.7	Pre-startup safety review for additions or significant modifications to the chlorine process or any new regulated chemical process.
3.8	Compliance audits at least every three years from 1999 to evaluate compliance. 
3.9	Incident investigation, to be conducted and documented for each incident that resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in a catastrophic release of chlorine from the facility.
3.10	Employee participation in the development and implementation of the facility RMP employee access to RMP information.

n policy on or near the chlorine system when chlorine in present in the affected section of the process.  The Hot Work Procedures are periodically reviewed.
3.12	Contractor management program, to ensure appropriate evaluation and selection of qualified contractors for work on or near the chlorine system, proper notification of contractors regarding known chlorine system hazards and the Tupelo WPCP emergency evacuation plan, limited access to the chlorine process and evaluation of contractor performance.

In addition to these elements, the chlorine storage area at the Tupelo WPCP is equipped with a chlorine leak detector that continuously monitors the air for chlorine gas.  If the chlorine sensor detects a specified level of chlorine, audio and visual alarms will be activated.  The alarm system is maintained and tested on a regular basis to ensure proper operation should there be a chlorine release.  Management of Change procedures will be used for the upgrades to the chlorine system.
